item.title: At ground zero, 9/11 anniversary now both public and private
item.description: NEW YORK (AP) — After years as a private commemoration, the anniversary of Sept. 11 at ground zero now also has become an occasion for public reflection on the site of the terror attacks.
item.media:text: NEW YORK (AP) — After years as a private commemoration, the anniversary of Sept. 11 at ground zero now also has become an occasion for public reflection on the site of the terror attacks.

item.title: New York designer denounces police killings from runway
item.description: Gunfire is not the typical soundtrack to a New York fashion show and graphic footage of racially charged police killings are not the typical pre-catwalk introduction. A wave of police killings of unarmed black men has become a defining issue in contemporary America, sparking a wave of protests and giving birth to a new generation of rights activists. The fashion pack is not renowned for its social conscience, but Jean-Raymond -- who dislikes being pigeonholed as a black designer -- says if the media choose to focus on his race, then he wants it on his own terms.
item.media:text: Gunfire is not the typical soundtrack to a New York fashion show and graphic footage of racially charged police killings are not the typical pre-catwalk introduction. A wave of police killings of unarmed black men has become a defining issue in contemporary America, sparking a wave of protests and giving birth to a new generation of rights activists. The fashion pack is not renowned for its social conscience, but Jean-Raymond -- who dislikes being pigeonholed as a black designer -- says if the media choose to focus on his race, then he wants it on his own terms.

item.title: Judge: Man unfit for trial in hedge-fund founder dad's death
item.description: NEW YORK (AP) — A man suspected of killing his hedge-fund founder father over an argument about his allowance is not mentally fit to stand trial and may be sent to a psychiatric facility as early as next week, a judge ruled Thursday.
item.media:text: NEW YORK (AP) — A man suspected of killing his hedge-fund founder father over an argument about his allowance is not mentally fit to stand trial and may be sent to a psychiatric facility as early as next week, a judge ruled Thursday.

item.title: Brady throws 4 TDs to TEs in 28-21 win
item.description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. (AP) — Whether sprinting out of the tunnel for warmups, watching former teammates and the Patriots owner carrying Lombardi Trophies, or tearing apart the Steelers, Tom Brady relished every moment of this NFL season opener.
item.media:text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. (AP) — Whether sprinting out of the tunnel for warmups, watching former teammates and the Patriots owner carrying Lombardi Trophies, or tearing apart the Steelers, Tom Brady relished every moment of this NFL season opener.

item.title: South Korean man gets 12 years for slashing US ambassador
item.description: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — A Seoul court on Friday handed a 12-year prison sentence to a South Korean man who slashed and seriously injured the U.S. ambassador during a March forum.
item.media:text: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — A Seoul court on Friday handed a 12-year prison sentence to a South Korean man who slashed and seriously injured the U.S. ambassador during a March forum.

item.title: Singapore ruling party popularity tested in general election
item.description: SINGAPORE (AP) — Singaporeans voted Friday in general elections that are expected to retain the ruling People's Action Party 50-year-old hold on power by another five years. But the percentage of votes the party garners will be closely watched as a barometer of its popularity during tough economic times.
item.media:text: SINGAPORE (AP) — Singaporeans voted Friday in general elections that are expected to retain the ruling People's Action Party 50-year-old hold on power by another five years. But the percentage of votes the party garners will be closely watched as a barometer of its popularity during tough economic times.

item.title: Venezuela opposition leader Lopez jailed for nearly 14 years
item.description: By Girish Gupta and Andrew Cawthorne CARACAS (Reuters) - Hardline Venezuelan opposition leader Leopoldo Lopez was jailed on Thursday for nearly 14 years on charges of inciting 2014 anti-government protests that spiraled into violence killing more than 40 people. The ruling enraged foes of socialist President Nicolas Maduro who say Lopez is an innocent scapegoat, but it brought cheers from grassroots government supporters who view the U.S.-educated activist as a dangerous conspirator. Lopez's case has become a cause celebre for opposition supporters over what they deem the Maduro government's trampling of human rights.
item.media:text: By Girish Gupta and Andrew Cawthorne CARACAS (Reuters) - Hardline Venezuelan opposition leader Leopoldo Lopez was jailed on Thursday for nearly 14 years on charges of inciting 2014 anti-government protests that spiraled into violence killing more than 40 people. The ruling enraged foes of socialist President Nicolas Maduro who say Lopez is an innocent scapegoat, but it brought cheers from grassroots government supporters who view the U.S.-educated activist as a dangerous conspirator. Lopez's case has become a cause celebre for opposition supporters over what they deem the Maduro government's trampling of human rights.

item.title: Japan charges Bitcoin exchange CEO with embezzlement: Jiji Press
item.description: Japanese prosecutors on Friday charged the head of collapsed Bitcoin exchange MtGox with embezzlement, Jiji Press news agency said, amid fraud allegations over the disappearance of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of the virtual currency. The charges, which could not be immediately confirmed, come after France-born Mark Karpeles, 30, was taken into police custody in Tokyo last month over the affair. Karpeles was first taken into custody over claims he fraudulently tinkered with data and transferred funds to other firms controlled by him dozens of times between 2011 and 2013.
item.media:text: Japanese prosecutors on Friday charged the head of collapsed Bitcoin exchange MtGox with embezzlement, Jiji Press news agency said, amid fraud allegations over the disappearance of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of the virtual currency. The charges, which could not be immediately confirmed, come after France-born Mark Karpeles, 30, was taken into police custody in Tokyo last month over the affair. Karpeles was first taken into custody over claims he fraudulently tinkered with data and transferred funds to other firms controlled by him dozens of times between 2011 and 2013.

item.title: Guatemala's rock star: Quiet jurist who took down president
item.description: GUATEMALA CITY (AP) — Guatemala's newest celebrity is a tall, stoic, 60-year-old jurist with thinning hair and a gray beard, who can't walk the streets without people approaching to shake his hand or snap a photo with him.
item.media:text: GUATEMALA CITY (AP) — Guatemala's newest celebrity is a tall, stoic, 60-year-old jurist with thinning hair and a gray beard, who can't walk the streets without people approaching to shake his hand or snap a photo with him.

item.title: Rescuers search for missing after Japanese city flooded
item.description: JOSO, Japan (AP) — Rescue workers searched for more than 20 missing people in a flooded city near Tokyo on Friday, as the sun came out a day after a raging river washed away houses and forced people to rooftops.
item.media:text: JOSO, Japan (AP) — Rescue workers searched for more than 20 missing people in a flooded city near Tokyo on Friday, as the sun came out a day after a raging river washed away houses and forced people to rooftops.

item.title: Steven Spielberg, Bill Ford team up on tolerance education
item.description: DEARBORN, Mich. (AP) — Academy Award-winning director Steven Spielberg and Ford Motor Co. Executive Chairman Bill Ford announced Thursday they are partnering to expand a multimedia program for Detroit-area students designed to foster tolerance.
item.media:text: DEARBORN, Mich. (AP) — Academy Award-winning director Steven Spielberg and Ford Motor Co. Executive Chairman Bill Ford announced Thursday they are partnering to expand a multimedia program for Detroit-area students designed to foster tolerance.

item.title: Hostages held in LA-area restaurant as police pursue carjacking suspect
item.description: Several people were being held hostage in a Los Angeles-area restaurant late on Thursday after a suspected carjacker barricaded himself inside the building following a police chase, law enforcement and media reported. The suspect had holed up inside a barbecue restaurant in the city of Downey, in southeast Los Angeles, police said. Broadcasters KNBC and KCAl9 said six people were taken hostage.

item.title: Police: 5 family members found dead in Minnesota home
item.description: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) — Five family members, including three children, were found dead in their lakeside home in an upscale western Minneapolis suburb on Thursday in what police said appeared to be a murder-suicide.
item.media:text: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) — Five family members, including three children, were found dead in their lakeside home in an upscale western Minneapolis suburb on Thursday in what police said appeared to be a murder-suicide.

item.title: Thousands of rescuers head to flood-hit Japanese city
item.description: Thousands of rescuers arrived in a deluged city north of Tokyo on Friday to help evacuate hundreds of trapped residents and search for 12 people missing after torrential rains triggered massive flooding. Heavy rain continued early Friday, threatening to worsen conditions in the wake of Typhoon Etau, which smashed through the country earlier this week bringing strong winds and causing travel chaos. Some 2,000 troops, police and firefighters were dispatched Friday morning to flooded areas where rescuers had worked through the night, public broadcaster NHK said.
item.media:text: Thousands of rescuers arrived in a deluged city north of Tokyo on Friday to help evacuate hundreds of trapped residents and search for 12 people missing after torrential rains triggered massive flooding. Heavy rain continued early Friday, threatening to worsen conditions in the wake of Typhoon Etau, which smashed through the country earlier this week bringing strong winds and causing travel chaos. Some 2,000 troops, police and firefighters were dispatched Friday morning to flooded areas where rescuers had worked through the night, public broadcaster NHK said.

item.title: Trump surges, Clinton losing to Sanders in Iowa: polls
item.description: Billionaire Donald Trump has extended his lead over the Republican presidential field, while Democratic overall frontrunner Hillary Clinton now trails underdog Bernie Sanders in the key early voting state of Iowa, polls showed. A CNN/ORC poll found Trump surging to 32 percent support nationally, becoming the first in the broad Republican field to top 30 percent in the race for the White House. The poll shows Ben Carson, a retired neurosurgeon, rising 10 points to take second place, with 19 percent.
item.media:text: Billionaire Donald Trump has extended his lead over the Republican presidential field, while Democratic overall frontrunner Hillary Clinton now trails underdog Bernie Sanders in the key early voting state of Iowa, polls showed. A CNN/ORC poll found Trump surging to 32 percent support nationally, becoming the first in the broad Republican field to top 30 percent in the race for the White House. The poll shows Ben Carson, a retired neurosurgeon, rising 10 points to take second place, with 19 percent.

item.title: UN strongly approves Palestinian proposal to raise flag
item.description: UNITED NATIONS (AP) — The U.N. General Assembly overwhelmingly approved a resolution Thursday allowing the Palestinians and the Holy See to raise their flags at U.N. headquarters — a symbolic step pursued by the Palestinians in their quest for an independent state.
item.media:text: UNITED NATIONS (AP) — The U.N. General Assembly overwhelmingly approved a resolution Thursday allowing the Palestinians and the Holy See to raise their flags at U.N. headquarters — a symbolic step pursued by the Palestinians in their quest for an independent state.

item.title: Jeb Bush's plan to regain front-runner status: Patience
item.description: By Steve Holland SALEM, N.H. (Reuters) - U.S. Republican presidential candidate Jeb Bush outlined a simple plan on Thursday for regaining his front-runner status: Patience, followed by more patience. With some of his supporters concerned about the rise of Donald Trump, Bush made clear he is not panicking, although he acknowledged he is no longer the front-runner in the early voting state of New Hampshire. Asked at a town hall event in Salem how he can regain the lead position among the 17 Republicans seeking the party's presidential nomination in 2016, Bush said: "Patience, more patience...You campaign hard in the early states.
item.media:text: By Steve Holland SALEM, N.H. (Reuters) - U.S. Republican presidential candidate Jeb Bush outlined a simple plan on Thursday for regaining his front-runner status: Patience, followed by more patience. With some of his supporters concerned about the rise of Donald Trump, Bush made clear he is not panicking, although he acknowledged he is no longer the front-runner in the early voting state of New Hampshire. Asked at a town hall event in Salem how he can regain the lead position among the 17 Republicans seeking the party's presidential nomination in 2016, Bush said: "Patience, more patience...You campaign hard in the early states.

item.title: Quartet of trophies on display at Patriots celebration
item.description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. (AP) — Everything was in place for the New England Patriots to celebrate their fourth Super Bowl championship in the NFL opener.
item.media:text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. (AP) — Everything was in place for the New England Patriots to celebrate their fourth Super Bowl championship in the NFL opener.

item.title: Marine killed, 18 injured in rollover at California base
item.description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. (AP) — One Marine was killed and 18 others injured Thursday in a single-vehicle rollover crash during routine training at Camp Pendleton Marine Base.

item.title: Appeals court blocks pesticide use over concerns about bees
item.description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — A federal appeals court Thursday blocked the use of a pesticide over concerns about its effect on honey bees, which have mysteriously disappeared across the country in recent years.

item.title: S. Korean gets 12 years for knife attack on US ambassador
item.description: The South Korean man behind a shocking knife attack that left the US ambassador in Seoul needing 80 stitches to a deep gash on his face, was convicted of attempted murder on Friday and jailed for 12 years. Prosecutors had sought a 15-year sentence for Kim Ki-Jong, 56, who lunged at Mark Lippert with a paring knife during a breakfast function in Seoul in March. In accepting the attempted murder charge, the Seoul Central District Court cited medical reports showing Kim had come close to severing the carotid artery in Lippert's neck.
item.media:text: The South Korean man behind a shocking knife attack that left the US ambassador in Seoul needing 80 stitches to a deep gash on his face, was convicted of attempted murder on Friday and jailed for 12 years. Prosecutors had sought a 15-year sentence for Kim Ki-Jong, 56, who lunged at Mark Lippert with a paring knife during a breakfast function in Seoul in March. In accepting the attempted murder charge, the Seoul Central District Court cited medical reports showing Kim had come close to severing the carotid artery in Lippert's neck.

item.title: Iowa (again), Georgia win 3rd night Miss America prelims
item.description: ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. (AP) — Miss Iowa continued racking up points in her march toward the 2016 Miss America crown on Thursday, adding a swimsuit preliminary title to her talent win two days earlier.
item.media:text: ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. (AP) — Miss Iowa continued racking up points in her march toward the 2016 Miss America crown on Thursday, adding a swimsuit preliminary title to her talent win two days earlier.

item.title: Asia stocks mostly higher on Wall Street tail wind
item.description: Asian stock markets mostly rose Friday, propelled by a tail wind from Wall Street and glimmers of improvement in some economies.
item.media:text: Asian stock markets mostly rose Friday, propelled by a tail wind from Wall Street and glimmers of improvement in some economies.

item.title: U.S. 'deeply troubled' by conviction of Venezuela's Lopez
item.description: CARACAS (Reuters) - U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Robert Jacobson said on Thursday she was "deeply troubled" by the sentencing of Venezuelan opposition leader Leopoldo Lopez to 13 years' prison. Jacobson, via Twitter, urged the defense of democracy and human rights in Venezuela. Washington had been urging President Nicolas Maduro's government to release Lopez, in jail since February 2014 on charges of inciting violence. (Reporting by Eyanir Chinea; Writing by Andrew Cawthorne; Editing by Shri Navaratnam)

item.title: Venezuelan opposition leader convicted of inciting violence
item.description: CARACAS, Venezuela (AP) — Jailed Venezuelan opposition leader Leopoldo Lopez was convicted and sentenced Thursday to almost 14 years in prison, the maximum allowed, for inciting violence as leader of protests last year in which several dozen people died.
item.media:text: CARACAS, Venezuela (AP) — Jailed Venezuelan opposition leader Leopoldo Lopez was convicted and sentenced Thursday to almost 14 years in prison, the maximum allowed, for inciting violence as leader of protests last year in which several dozen people died.

item.title: Pats fans find few friends in enemy territory for NFL opener
item.description: CHICAGO (AP) — Patriots fans around the country are looking for sports bars where they won't get booed out of the joint when glamour-boy quarterback Tom Brady gets rolling.
item.media:text: CHICAGO (AP) — Patriots fans around the country are looking for sports bars where they won't get booed out of the joint when glamour-boy quarterback Tom Brady gets rolling.

item.title: Fiorina to join next US Republican debate: host CNN
item.description: Washington (AFP) - The 11 leading candidates for the Republican presidential nomination will be on stage for next week's debate, including businesswoman Carly Fiorina, host CNN announced after it changed the rules to let her in.
item.media:text: Washington (AFP) - The 11 leading candidates for the Republican presidential nomination will be on stage for next week's debate, including businesswoman Carly Fiorina, host CNN announced after it changed the rules to let her in.

item.title: Senate Democrats block effort to kill Iran nuclear deal
item.description: By Patricia Zengerle and Richard Cowan WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. President Barack Obama achieved perhaps the greatest foreign policy victory of his six years in office on Thursday, when a Republican-backed effort to kill the Iran nuclear agreement was narrowly blocked in the U.S. Senate, clearing the way for the deal's implementation. Forty Democrats and two independents voted to block a resolution disapproving of the pact in the 100-member chamber, one more than the minimum needed to keep it from advancing. "This vote is a victory for diplomacy, for American national security, and for the safety and security of the world," Obama said in a statement after a vote he termed "an historic step forward." Senate Republicans insisted the fight was not over, however.
item.media:text: By Patricia Zengerle and Richard Cowan WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. President Barack Obama achieved perhaps the greatest foreign policy victory of his six years in office on Thursday, when a Republican-backed effort to kill the Iran nuclear agreement was narrowly blocked in the U.S. Senate, clearing the way for the deal's implementation. Forty Democrats and two independents voted to block a resolution disapproving of the pact in the 100-member chamber, one more than the minimum needed to keep it from advancing. "This vote is a victory for diplomacy, for American national security, and for the safety and security of the world," Obama said in a statement after a vote he termed "an historic step forward." Senate Republicans insisted the fight was not over, however.

item.title: Arrest made in case of Hawaiian king statue's spear
item.description: HILO, Hawaii (AP) — Police have arrested a man in connection with a spear that was taken from King Kamehameha's statue on Hawaii's Big Island.

item.title: Arizona on alert over sniper freeway shootings
item.description: Eleven shootings have taken place on or near Intestate 10 in the southwestern US state since August 29, the latest of which was on Thursday when a semi-trailer was struck in the side by a bullet, police told AFP. The only injury has been a teenage girl who was cut by flying glass when the window of the car in which she was traveling was shattered by a bullet. Bart Graves, a spokesman for Arizona state police, said there are fears one or more snipers may be behind the attacks.
item.media:text: Eleven shootings have taken place on or near Intestate 10 in the southwestern US state since August 29, the latest of which was on Thursday when a semi-trailer was struck in the side by a bullet, police told AFP. The only injury has been a teenage girl who was cut by flying glass when the window of the car in which she was traveling was shattered by a bullet. Bart Graves, a spokesman for Arizona state police, said there are fears one or more snipers may be behind the attacks.

item.title: Venezuelan opposition leader found guilty of inciting violence for role in 2014 protests
item.description: CARACAS, Venezuela (AP) — Venezuelan opposition leader found guilty of inciting violence for role in 2014 protests.

item.title: Oakland Zoo auctioning paintings by its animals
item.description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — An auction for 32 colorful paintings produced by elephants, giraffes, river otters and even a cockroach at the Oakland Zoo is underway with more than half a dozen bids on the art work.
item.media:text: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — An auction for 32 colorful paintings produced by elephants, giraffes, river otters and even a cockroach at the Oakland Zoo is underway with more than half a dozen bids on the art work.

item.title: Iran deal no reason to halt work on Gulf missile shield: U.S. experts
item.description: By Andrea Shalal WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The Unites States will keep working on a regional missile defense system in the Gulf despite progress on the Iran nuclear deal, current and former U.S. military officials said on Thursday while warning that Iran has the largest inventory of short- and medium-range cruise and ballistic missiles in the region. The comments came as a Republican-backed effort to kill the Iran nuclear agreement was narrowly blocked in the U.S. Senate, handing President Barack Obama a huge victory and clearing the way for the deal's implementation. Robert Scher, assistant defense secretary for strategy, plans and capabilities, told lawmakers the Pentagon would continue to push for cooperative missile defense programs since the nuclear deal did not cover Iran's work on ballistic missiles.

item.title: Biden says he's unsure he can commit fully to be president
item.description: NEW YORK (AP) — Vice President Joe Biden described himself Thursday as overwhelmed at times by his son's death and unconvinced he could commit fully to being president, in an emotional interview that cast a deep pall over his deliberations about the 2016 presidential race.
item.media:text: NEW YORK (AP) — Vice President Joe Biden described himself Thursday as overwhelmed at times by his son's death and unconvinced he could commit fully to being president, in an emotional interview that cast a deep pall over his deliberations about the 2016 presidential race.

item.title: Obama orders US to admit 10,000 Syrian refugees
item.description: President Barack Obama has asked for at least 10,000 Syrian refugees to be admitted to the United States next year, amid criticism his government has done too little to help. Spokesman Josh Earnest on Thursday said Obama had asked staff to "scale up" the number of refugee admissions, which are likely to total around 1,800 in the fiscal year ending September 30. "He has informed his team that he would like them to make preparations to accept at least 10,000 Syrian refugees in the next fiscal year," said Earnest.

item.title: Amid campaign concerns, Clinton seeks to rally her loyalists
item.description: COLUMBUS, Ohio (AP) — With poll numbers declining and email questions persisting, Hillary Rodham Clinton labored Thursday to shore up support among some of her strongest backers and ease concerns about the trajectory of her presidential campaign.
item.media:text: COLUMBUS, Ohio (AP) — With poll numbers declining and email questions persisting, Hillary Rodham Clinton labored Thursday to shore up support among some of her strongest backers and ease concerns about the trajectory of her presidential campaign.

item.title: Arizona police confirm 11th vehicle attack, seek tips
item.description: PHOENIX (AP) — The search for a suspect in a string of Phoenix freeway shootings took on a frenzied pace Thursday, with a panicked public flooding a police hotline with tips.
item.media:text: PHOENIX (AP) — The search for a suspect in a string of Phoenix freeway shootings took on a frenzied pace Thursday, with a panicked public flooding a police hotline with tips.

item.title: Charging decision doesn't end police killing cases
item.description: SPOKANE, Wash. (AP) — The decision by a local prosecutor to not charge three Pasco police officers with any crimes in the shooting death of a rock-throwing Mexican immigrant hardly concludes the matter.
item.media:text: SPOKANE, Wash. (AP) — The decision by a local prosecutor to not charge three Pasco police officers with any crimes in the shooting death of a rock-throwing Mexican immigrant hardly concludes the matter.

item.title: Cowboys' Hardy won't challenge NFL's 4-game ban in court
item.description: IRVING, Texas (AP) — Suspended Dallas defensive end Greg Hardy won't challenge the NFL in federal court over his four-game ban for his role in a domestic violence case.
item.media:text: IRVING, Texas (AP) — Suspended Dallas defensive end Greg Hardy won't challenge the NFL in federal court over his four-game ban for his role in a domestic violence case.
